<P align="center"><FONT size="2">89
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, Inc.<BR>
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<HR size="2" noshade>
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="79%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2"><B>12.</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization
Act/Aviation and Transportation Security Act</B>
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;22, 2001, President Bush signed into law the Air
Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act (&#147;the
Stabilization Act&#148;). The Stabilization Act provided cash grants to
commercial air carriers as compensation for: (1)&nbsp;direct losses
incurred beginning with the terrorist attacks on September&nbsp;11, 2001
as a result of any FAA mandated ground stop order issued by the
Secretary of Transportation (and for any subsequent order which
continues or renews such a stoppage), and (2)&nbsp;incremental losses
incurred during the period beginning September&nbsp;11, 2001 and ending
December&nbsp;31, 2001 as a direct result of such attacks. The Company
was entitled to receive cash grants under these provisions. The
Company has complied with the requirements of the Stabilization Act
and submitted its final claim. The Company and the Airline
Stabilization Review Team have reached agreement on $10.7&nbsp;million as
the total amount the Company was eligible to receive as direct
compensation under the Stabilization Act. The Company has recorded
and received payment of $9.7&nbsp;million and $0.9&nbsp;million as government
compensation for the years 2001 and 2002, respectively. All amounts
received as government compensation are subject to additional audit
by the federal government for the next five years.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">On November&nbsp;19, 2001 the President signed into law the Aviation and
Transportation Security Act (the &#147;Security Act&#148;). The Security Act
requires heightened passenger, baggage and cargo security measures be
adopted as well as enhanced airport security procedures. The
Security Act created the Transportation Security Administration
(&#147;TSA&#148;) that has taken over from the air carriers the reasonability
for conducting the screening of passengers and their baggage. The
TSA assumed both of the Company&#146;s passenger screening contracts on
February&nbsp;17, 2002. Air carriers continue to have responsibility for
aircraft security, employee background checks, the security of air
carrier airport facilities and other security related functions.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">The activities of the TSA are to be funded in part by the application
of a $2.50 per passenger enplanement security fee (subject to a
maximum of $5.00 per one way trip) and payment by all passenger
carriers of a sum not exceeding each carrier&#146;s passenger and baggage
screening cost incurred in calendar year 2000. The TSA is required
to deploy federal air marshals on an increased number of passenger
flights. The Security Act imposes new and increased requirements for
air carrier employee background checks and additional security
training of flight and cabin crew personnel. These additional and
new requirements have increased the security related costs of the
Company. The Security Act also mandates and the FAA has adopted new
rules requiring the strengthening of cockpit doors, some of the costs
of</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2">90
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, Inc.<BR>
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<HR size="2" noshade>
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="79%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">which have been reimbursed by the FAA. The Company has completed
all mandatory cockpit door modifications and has been reimbursed $2.7
million under the Security Act, although the cost of such
modifications exceeded this amount. At times when the aviation
security threat level is elevated by the Department of Homeland
Security the Company may experience security-related disruptions,
including reduced passenger demand, resulting from enhanced passenger
screening at airports and possible flight cancellations. The Company
believes that its exposure to such disruptions is no greater than
that faced by other providers of regional air carrier services.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;16, 2003, Congress passed the Emergency Wartime Supplemental
Appropriations Act (&#147;the Act&#148;). The Act makes available
approximately $2.3&nbsp;billion to United States flag air carriers, a
portion of which is based on each carrier&#146;s proportional share of the
amounts remitted in passenger and carrier security fees by eligible
air carriers to the TSA under the Stabilization Act which was earlier enacted
by Congress. In the second quarter of 2003, the Company received and
recorded $1.5&nbsp;million in compensation under the Act. In addition to
refunding previously remitted security fees, the Act waived the
collection and payment by carriers of any passenger or carrier
security fees imposed by the Stabilization Act for the period June&nbsp;1,
2003 through September&nbsp;30. 2003. The Act also extended by 24&nbsp;months
the government&#146;s war risk insurance program which otherwise would
have expired on December&nbsp;31, 2002. The FAA provides war risk
insurance to carriers pursuant to the Act through short-term
policies, which it extends from time to time. The Company
anticipates renewing the insurance through the FAA as long as it is
available.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2"><B>13.</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Subsequent<BR>
Event</B>
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">In January&nbsp;2004 the Company executed the lease agreements for the first four Airbus A319 aircraft with a third
party leasing company. The aircraft will be delivered one a month beginning in September&nbsp;2004 and will have an
initial term of five years. The leases require the Company to put up a security deposit and to make monthly rent
and maintenance reserve payments. Annual cash rent for the four aircraft is estimated to be approximately $12.7
million.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2"><B>14.</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
<B>Litigation</B>
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">The Company is involved in legal proceedings related to the insolvency of Fairchild Dornier GmbH (&#147;Fairchild&#148;),
which was initiated in 2002. The Company holds a bond in the amount of $1.2&nbsp;million from an independent
insurance company that was delivered to secure deposits placed with Fairchild for undelivered aircraft, and has
made a demand for payment under this bond. Fairchild&#146;s insolvency trustee has made a claim for the collateral
posted with the insurance company, and the insurance company has withheld payment of the bond. The matter is
presently with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for
the Western District of Texas. The Company has fully reserved for
this receivable.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2">91
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, Inc.<BR>
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<HR size="2" noshade>
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="79%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;14, 2003, the Company commenced arbitration proceedings against GE Engine Services, Inc. (&#147;GE&#148;). In
the proceeding, the Company seeks a ruling by an arbitrator that it has the right to remove any or all engines
from the scope of an engine services agreement with GE governing the scheduled and unscheduled repair of ACA&#146;s
CRJ jet engines. GE has also requested that the arbitration also address the issue of whether GE is owed certain
amounts it claims it is owed pursuant to the agreement. The parties are presently addressing preliminary
procedures in advance of proceeding with this arbitration. The Company believes that it has adequately reserved
for GE&#146;s counterclaim in the event that an arbitrator rules in favor of GE&#146;s counterclaim. If the arbitrator
were to rule against the Company&#146;s interpretation of the agreement, covered engines will remain subject to the
agreement for the balance of the term of the agreement.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">The Company has been named in several lawsuits arising from the terrorist activities of September&nbsp;11, 2001.
These actions were commenced by or on behalf of individuals who were injured or killed as a result of the
hijackings of the four flights. These actions seek compensatory and punitive damages. However, pursuant to the
Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act, the Company&#146;s liability for these claims is limited to
the Company&#146;s liability insurance. In each case, the plaintiffs have named the airlines operating at the
airports from which the flights originated, including the Company, under the theory that all of the airlines are
jointly responsible for the alleged security breaches by the airport security contractor. The court recently
denied the motion of American Airlines and other defendants, including the Company, seeking dismissal of all
ground victim claims on the basis that the airline defendants do not owe a duty as a matter of law to individuals
injured or killed on the ground. The Company anticipates that it will raise other defenses including its
assertion that it is not responsible for the incidents as it had no control over the security checkpoints through
which the hijackers allegedly gained access to the hijacked aircraft. Numerous lawsuits alleging this claim were
filed during the third quarter of 2003 as a result of the possible expiration of certain statutes of
limitations. A total of 81 complaints against the Company are known to be pending. Of the 81 complaints, 37 are
active, as the claimants have formally opted out of the Victim Compensation Fund. The remaining 44 claimants are
required to elect whether or not to opt out of the Victim Compensation Fund. The claimants who have filed are
required to serve their complaints by March&nbsp;7, 2004 if they wish to proceed. The Company anticipates that other
similar lawsuits could be filed on behalf of other victims.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2">92
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, Inc.<BR>
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<HR size="2" noshade>
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="79%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">From time to time, claims are made against the Company with respect to activities arising from its airline
operations. Typically these involve injuries or damages incurred by passengers and are considered routine to the
industry. On April&nbsp;1, 2002, one of the Company&#146;s insurers on its comprehensive aviation liability policy, Legion
Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Mutual Risk Management Ltd. (&#147;Legion&#148;), was placed into rehabilitation by the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, its state of incorporation. The rehabilitation proceeding is styled Koken v.
Legion Insurance Company, No.&nbsp;183 M.D. 2002 (Pa. Commw. Ct.), and is before Judge Leavitt. Currently, Legion can
pay no claims, expenses or other items of debt without approval from Pennsylvania, resulting in the Company
directly carrying the corresponding exposure related to Legion&#146;s contribution percentage for payouts of claims
and expenses that Legion represented on the Company&#146;s all-risk hull and liability insurance for the 1999, 2000,
2001 and 2002 policy years. Those contribution percentages are 15% for claims arising from incidents occurring
in 1999, 19% for 2000, 15% for 2001, and 8.5% for the first quarter of 2002. Legion ceased to be an insurer for
the Company as of April&nbsp;1, 2002, and there is, therefore, no exposure with respect to Legion for claims arising
after that date.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">The insurance held by Legion on the Company&#146;s policy was fully covered by reinsurance, which means that other
carriers are contractually obligated to cover all claims that are direct obligations of Legion. It is
additionally believed that a &#147;cut-through&#148; provision exists that causes funds to pass directly from the
reinsurers to the Company in situations such as the rehabilitation or insolvency of a primary insurer. Other
companies, including American Airlines, Inc. (&#147;American&#148;), have similar policy provisions. American and others
intervened in the Legion rehabilitation and moved to have the cut-through provisions enforced. However, other
creditors of Legion and the Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner maintained that the funds should apply to
Legion&#146;s other obligations. On June&nbsp;26, 2003, the Pennsylvania Commonwealth Court ruled in American&#146;s favor and
entered an order enforcing the cut-through provisions. The Court ruled that the reinsurance contract proceeds at
issue were not general assets of the Legion estate. On July&nbsp;25, 2003, the Court entered an Order of Liquidation
that incorporated the June&nbsp;26, 2003 ruling. The Order provided a means whereby the Company could intervene to
assert rights to its own reinsurance. The Company filed a motion to intervene which remains outstanding. The
Insurance Commissioner and others appealed the Court&#146;s ruling regarding reinsurance and the Pennsylvania Supreme
Court entered an automatic supersedeas that stayed the matter at the trial level. If upheld on appeal, the
ruling provides an avenue whereby the Company can seek to have its cut-through provision enforced. However, if
the ruling is overturned on appeal, the Company will likely be underinsured for these</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2">93
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="79%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">claims at the percentages
set forth above. This underinsurance would include September&nbsp;11 related lawsuits and any other similar lawsuits
that are brought against the Company. The Company has accrued reserves for its likely exposure on claims known
to date. No reserves have been accrued for the September&nbsp;11 related claims.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">The Company is currently involved in litigation against Mesa Air Group, Inc. (&#147;Mesa&#148;) arising from Mesa&#146;s
proposed exchange offer and consent solicitation to replace the Company&#146;s board of directors, both of which Mesa
announced in October&nbsp;2003. In its complaint filed with the United States District Court for the District of
Columbia on October&nbsp;27, 2003, and as subsequently amended, the Company alleged that Mesa made materially false
and misleading statements and omissions in violation of Sections&nbsp;14(a) and (e)&nbsp;of the Securities Exchange Act of
1934 in connection with its consent solicitation and potential exchange offer. The complaint alleged, among
other things, that (i)&nbsp;Mesa concealed its own direct and material interests in seeking to remove the Company&#146;s
board of directors; (ii)&nbsp;Mesa made several false and misleading statements about its November&nbsp;12, 2003 memorandum
of understanding with United Air Lines, Inc. (the &#147;United MOU&#148;); (iii)&nbsp;Mesa failed to disclose United Air Lines
(&#147;United&#148;) as a participant in its consent solicitation and proposed transaction; (iv)&nbsp;Mesa made materially false
and misleading statements about the independence, beliefs, intentions and qualifications of Mesa&#146;s nominees to
the Company&#146;s board of directors; (v)&nbsp;Mesa failed to disclose multiple incidents of questionable trading in Mesa
stock by insiders; and (vi)&nbsp;Mesa failed to disclose conflicts of interests and self-dealing by Mesa&#146;s directors.
On November&nbsp;26, 2003, the Company amended its complaint to further allege that Mesa&#146;s consent solicitation and
proposed exchange offer violated Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act and Section&nbsp;7 of the Clayton Act by seeking, in
concert with United, to prevent the Company from entering relevant markets through launching Independence Air.
For the alleged antitrust violations, the Company sought injunctive relief to prevent Mesa from proceeding with
the consent solicitation or proposed exchange offer, damages, and attorneys&#146; fees. On December&nbsp;18, 2003, the
District Court entered a preliminary injunction with respect to the Company&#146;s antitrust claim under Section&nbsp;1 of
the Sherman Act, enjoining Mesa from proceeding with its consent solicitation or exchange offer pending final
resolution of the matter. The Court denied the Company&#146;s separate requests for preliminary relief under Section
14(a) and 14(e) of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 and Section&nbsp;7 of the Clayton Act. On January&nbsp;9, 2004,
the Company posted a $10,000,000 cash bond in connection with the preliminary injunction as required by the
District Court&#146;s order dated December&nbsp;30, 2003. At the Court&#146;s direction, the cash bond was placed in an
interest bearing account invested in Treasury Bills. On January&nbsp;20, 2004, Mesa filed a Notice of Appeal to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2">94
</FONT>

    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">Columbia Circuit from the District Court&#146;s order entering a
preliminary injunction under Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act. If the court were to determine that Mesa was
wrongfully enjoined, Mesa may have a right to seek payment for costs or damages incurred as a result of the
injunction. The Company believes the preliminary injunction was properly entered and that the District Court&#146;s
decision will be upheld on appeal, and will vigorously defend on appeal.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;10, 2004, Mesa filed a counterclaim against the Company, alleging that the Company&#146;s preliminary
proxy statement and other public statements made in connection with Mesa&#146;s consent solicitation and the Company&#146;s
plans to launch Independence Air were materially false and misleading, in violation of Section&nbsp;14(a) of the
Exchange Act. More specifically, Mesa alleged that the Company (i)&nbsp;failed to disclose the terms of its November
2003 memorandum of understanding with Airbus Industrie AVSA for the purchase of new aircraft, (ii)&nbsp;failed to
disclose the risks and capital requirements of the Company&#146;s plan to change its business model and launch a new
independent low-fare airline; (iii)&nbsp;failed to give meaningful consideration to Mesa&#146;s initial proposal to acquire
the Company; and (iv)&nbsp;failed to disclose that it had arranged for the delivery from a Company employee of a
consent form to Mesa&#146;s solicitation, in order to trigger the time period for Mesa to solicit consents, even
though Mesa&#146;s solicitation materials had not been cleared by the SEC. In the counterclaim, Mesa seeks, among
other things, an order (i)&nbsp;declaring that the Company&#146;s public statements in connection with Mesa&#146;s consent
solicitation and the Company&#146;s plan to launch an independent, low-fare airline violated Section&nbsp;14(a) of the
Exchange Act, (ii)&nbsp;requiring the Company to issue corrective disclosures, and (iii)&nbsp;enjoining the Company from
making any further materially false and misleading statements in connection with Mesa&#146;s consent solicitation and
the Company&#146;s plan to launch an independent, low-fare airline. The Company believes the counterclaim lacks merit
and will, if necessary, vigorously contest the allegations set forth therein. The Company incurred approximately
$9.6&nbsp;million in expenses related to its defense of Mesa&#146;s hostile takeover offer.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;18, 2003, the Company received a Civil Investigative Demand (&#147;CID&#148;) from the Antitrust Division of
the United States Department of Justice (&#147;DOJ&#148;) relating to an ongoing DOJ antitrust investigation. As disclosed
in the CID, the investigation concerns the proposed acquisition of the Company by Mesa, and possible violations
by Mesa of Section&nbsp;1 of the Sherman Act and Section&nbsp;7 of the Clayton Act. On December&nbsp;19, 2003, the Company was
advised by the DOJ that similar CIDs had been issued to both Mesa and United in connection with the same
investigation. The Company is cooperating fully with the DOJ&#146;s investigation.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">The FAA has made the Company aware that it has reviewed and is seeking assurances with respect to certain Company
maintenance program time tracking and related maintenance practices. In connection with this, the FAA previously
informed the Company that it needed to satisfy the FAA&#146;s concerns prior to adding additional aircraft to its
operations. The Company has responded to the issues raised by the FAA and satisfied its concerns to the extent
that the FAA permitted the Company to add two new CRJ aircraft to its operations effective October&nbsp;28, 2003. The
Company continues to work closely with the FAA and believes that it will be able to continue to assure the FAA
that its maintenance tracking and related practices meet and exceed FAA requirements, without any interruption in
its business plans. However, the FAA could seek to impose a civil penalty in connection with this matter. In
addition to this matter, the Company is the subject of ongoing FAA and TSA civil penalty cases relating to
alleged violations of FAA and TSA enforced rules and regulations. The Company believes that the number of such
cases and the amount of the civil penalties sought by the FAA and TSA is consistent with the experience of other
airlines with operations of the size and scope of those provided by the Company, and that the disposition of
these cases is not likely to have a material effect on the Company&#146;s financial position or the results of its
operations.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

is subjective and judgmental in nature; therefore, fair value estimates, especially for less marketable

different.</FONT></TD>

    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px"><FONT size="2">Long-term debt</FONT></DIV></TD>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, Inc.<BR>
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<HR size="2" noshade>
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="73%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2"><B>17.</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2"><B>Recent Accounting<BR>
Pronouncements</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left"><FONT size="2">In January&nbsp;2003, the Financial
Accounting Standards Board issued
FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46, (&#147;FIN
46&#148;) &#147;Consolidation of Variable
Interest Entities,&#148; (&#147;VIEs&#148;), an
interpretation of Accounting
Research Bulletin No.&nbsp;51,
&#147;Consolidated Financial Statements.&#148;
This interpretation was revised by
the Financial Accounting Standards
Board in December&nbsp;2003. This
interpretation requires an existing
unconsolidated variable interest
entity to be consolidated by its
primary beneficiary if the entity
has (1)&nbsp;an insufficient amount of
equity to absorb the entity&#146;s
expected losses, (2)&nbsp;equity owners
as a group are not able to make
decisions about the entity&#146;s
activities, or (3)&nbsp;equity that does
not absorb the entity&#146;s losses or
receive the entity&#146;s residual
returns. The primary beneficiary is
the party that absorbs a majority of
the entity&#146;s expected losses,
receives a majority of its expected
residual returns, or both, as a
result of holding variable
interests, which are the ownership,
contractual, or other pecuniary
interests in an entity. As a
result, variable interest entities
can arise from items such as lease
agreements, loan arrangements,
guarantees or service contracts.
Effective February&nbsp;1, 2003, the
Company adopted the requirement of
FIN 46 for any interests in VIEs
acquired after January&nbsp;31, 2003.
Effective December&nbsp;2003, the Company
adopted all requirements of the
revised FIN 46.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left"><FONT size="2">The Company has variable interests
in the following types of variable
interest entities:</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2"><U><I>Aircraft Leases</I></U>. The Company is the
lessee in a series of leveraged
operating lease transactions
relating to four J-41s and six CRJs
in conjunction with the issuances of
the Equipment Notes described in
Note 4. The lessors are trusts
established specifically to
purchase, finance and lease aircraft
to the Company. These leasing
entities meet the criteria for
variable interest entities. Based on
analysis by the Company, the terms
of the lease were consistent with
market terms at the inception of the
lease and do not contain a residual
value guarantee. However, the lease
agreements do contain a fixed price
purchase option on a specific date
during the lease term. The Company
has not consolidated the related
trusts upon application of FIN 46
because it believes that it is not
the primary beneficiary based on the
analysis performed that takes into
account the purchase options. The Company&#146;s
anticipated maximum exposure under
these leases is the remaining lease
payments, which are reflected in
future lease commitments in Note 6.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2"><U><I>Airport Hangar Lease</I></U><I>. </I>The Company is
the lessee of a hangar located at
Dulles International Airport under a
long-term operating lease and is
also the guarantor of approximately
$12.3&nbsp;million of underlying debt and
interest, thereon, issued by the
Industrial Development Authority of</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">98
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, Inc.<BR>
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<HR size="2" noshade>
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="10%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="73%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
&nbsp;
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">Loudon County, Virginia for the
construction of the facility. The
hangar is leased from the
Metropolitan Washington Airports
Authority, a government agency that
holds title to the property. The
Company has not consolidated the
entity under the requirements of FIN
46 because arrangements with
governmental entities and financing
entities established by governmental
agencies are not applicable to this
interpretation. The payments for
the underlying debt are included as
part of the operating lease
agreement. The Company&#146;s
anticipated maximum exposure under
this lease is the remaining lease
payments, which are reflected in
future lease commitments in Note 6.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left"><FONT size="2">In November&nbsp;2002, the Financial
Accounting Standards Board issued
FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;45,
&#147;Guarantor&#146;s Accounting and
Disclosure Requirements for
Guarantees, Including Indirect
Guarantees of Indebtedness of
Others,&#148; an interpretation of FASB
Statements No.&nbsp;5, 57 and 107 and
rescission of FASB Interpretation
No.&nbsp;34. This interpretation outlines
disclosure requirements in a
guarantor&#146;s financial statements
relating to any obligations under
guarantees for which it may have
potential risk or liability, as well
as clarifies a guarantor&#146;s
requirement to recognize a liability
for the fair value, at the inception
of the guarantee, of an obligation
under that guarantee. The initial
recognition and measurement
provisions of this interpretation
are effective for guarantees issued
or modified after December&nbsp;31, 2002
and the disclosure requirements are
effective for financial statements
of interim or annual periods ending
after December&nbsp;15, 2002. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2003, we have not
provided any guarantees that would
require recognition or disclosure as
liabilities under this
interpretation.</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="3" valign="top" align="left"><FONT size="2">Effective January&nbsp;1, 2003, the
Company adopted Statement No.&nbsp;146,
&#147;Accounting for Costs Associated
with Exit or Disposal Activities&#148;,
which requires that liabilities for
the costs associated with exit or
disposal activities be recognized
when the liabilities are incurred,
rather than when an entity commits
to an exit plan. Adoption of this
statement changes the timing of the
liability and expense recognition
related to exit or disposal
activities, but not the ultimate
amount of such expenses. See Note
11 of Notes to Condensed
Consolidated Financial Statements
for the impact of this statement on
the Company&#146;s plan to retire its
J-41 aircraft fleet.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2">99

<P align="right"><FONT size="2"><B>Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings, Inc.<BR>
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B><BR>
<HR size="2" noshade>
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><SUP>1 </SUP>In the second and fourth quarters of 2003, the Company recorded aircraft early retirement charges. The amount of the charges were $(34.6) million
(pre-tax) credit in the second quarter to reverse amounts recorded in the years ended 2001 and 2002 and $6.9&nbsp;million (pre-tax) in the fourth quarter.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><SUP>2 </SUP>In the second, third and fourth quarters of 2002, the Company recorded aircraft early retirement charges. The amount of the charges were $(4.8) million
(pre-tax) credit in the second quarter to reverse amounts recorded in the fourth quarter of 2001, $7.6&nbsp;million (pre-tax) in the third quarter, and $21.5
million in the fourth quarter.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><SUP>3 </SUP>Includes government compensation of $1.5&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><SUP>4 </SUP>Includes government compensation of $0.9&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">Note: The sum of the four quarters may not equal the totals for the year due to rounding of quarterly results.
</FONT>




<P align="center"><FONT size="2">101
</FONT>

<!-- link2 "Item&nbsp;9. Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure" -->

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Item&nbsp;9. Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure</B>
</FONT>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;None to report.

<!-- link2 "Item&nbsp;9A. Controls and Procedures" -->

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Item&nbsp;9A. Controls and Procedures</B>
</FONT>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2003 the Company carried out an evaluation, under the
supervision and with the participation of the Company&#146;s management, including
the Company&#146;s principal executive officer and principal financial officer, of
the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company&#146;s disclosure
controls and procedures pursuant to Exchange Act Rule&nbsp;13a-14 and 13a&#150;15.
Disclosure controls and procedures include controls and other procedures
designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the Company&#146;s
reports filed under the Exchange Act, such as this Form 10-K, is properly
recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods required
by the Securities and Exchange Commission&#146;s rules and forms. Management
necessarily applied its judgment in assessing the costs and benefits of such
controls and procedures that, by their nature, can provide only reasonable
assurance regarding management&#146;s control objectives. Management does not expect
that its disclosure controls and procedures will prevent all errors and fraud.
A control system, irrespective of how well it is designed and operated, can
only provide reasonable assurance, and cannot guarantee, that it will succeed
in its stated objectives.
</FONT>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based upon the foregoing evaluation, the principal executive officer and
principal financial officer concluded that the Company&#146;s disclosure controls
and procedures are effective in timely alerting them to material information
relating to the Company (including its consolidated subsidiaries) required to
be included in the Company&#146;s periodic SEC reports. In addition, during the
period covered by this annual report, there have been no changes to the
Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting that have materially
affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company&#146;s internal
control over financial reporting.
</FONT>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has two equity compensation plans that were not approved by
shareholders, pursuant to which options, rights or warrants may be granted:
the Non-Executive Officer Stock Option Plan (the &#147;Non-Executive Officer Plan&#148;)
and the Non-Officer Option Grant Program (the &#147;Non-Officer Option Program&#148;).
The Company&#146;s Board of Directors approved these two plans in 2000.
</FONT>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Non-Executive Officer Stock Option Plan</I>
</FONT>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Non-Executive Officer Plan is substantially identical to the Company&#146;s
2000 Stock Incentive Plan, which was approved by shareholders. The
Non-Executive Officer Plan allows the Company to grant equity compensation
under non-qualified stock options and restricted stock awards. Eligible
participants are employees, as defined under Securities and Exchange Commission
Form S-8, and prospective employees of the Company or any of its affiliates who
are not executives or directors of the Company. A maximum of 2&nbsp;million shares
of common stock are authorized for issuance under the Non-Executive Officer
Stock Option Plan. The exercise price of options granted under the plan can
not be less than 100% of the fair market value of a share of the Company&#146;s
stock on the option grant date. Awards are granted by the Chief Executive
Officer of the Company with approval from the Compensation Committee of the
Board of Directors. The terms of awards granted under the Non-Executive
Officer Plan, including vesting, forfeiture, post-termination exercisability
and the effects (if any) of a change in control, are set by the plan
administrator subject to certain restrictions set forth in the Non-Executive
Officer Plan.
</FONT>



<P align="center"><FONT size="2">103
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><I>Non-Officer Option Grant Program</I>
</FONT>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There are 400,000 shares reserved for issuance under the Non-Officer
Option Program. Options granted under the Non-Officer Option Program are
subject to the same terms as non-qualified stock options granted under the
Company&#146;s 1995 Stock Incentive Plan or the Company&#146;s 2000 Stock Incentive Plan
(both of which were approved by shareholders), as specified in the terms of any
such grant. The exercise price of options granted under the plan can not be
less than 100% of the fair market value of a share of the Company&#146;s stock on
the option grant date. Options are granted by the Chief Executive Officer of
the Company with approval from the Compensation Committee of the Board of
Directors. Stock options granted under the Non-Officer Option Program
generally vest over a period ranging from three to five years and expire 10
years after the date of grant.
</FONT>


<P align="left"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other information required by this Item is hereby incorporated by
reference from the Company&#146;s definitive proxy statement, which is expected to
be filed pursuant to Regulation&nbsp;14A of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 not
later than 120&nbsp;days after the end of the fiscal year covered by this report.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2"><B>PART IV</B>
</FONT>

<!-- link2 "Item&nbsp;15. Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules and Reports on Form&nbsp;8-K." -->

<P align="left"><FONT size="2"><B>Item&nbsp;15. Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedules and Reports on Form&nbsp;8-K</B>
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="0%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="91%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">
(a)
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right" valign="top"><FONT size="2"><br>
</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="top"><FONT size="2">1.<br>
</FONT></TD>
    <TD nowrap valign="top"><FONT size="2"><br>
</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">Financial Statements</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="top"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
